elements.text: PART ONE
OPENING THEME
SCENE 1. INT. ADRIC’S HOUSE.
FX: A SNOWSTORM BLOWS OUTSIDE. INSIDE, A FIRE CRACKLES. ADRIC’S
USING A COMM-LINK. RESPONSE IS DISTORTED.

Neeka? .. It’s Adric. There’s some weather interference on the comm-link, another ice-storm. Just checking to see how you are. Well, you can’t blame me for worrying, you are the baby of the family. (LAUGHS AT RESPONSE) And I’m never going to let you forget it. The programme’s going fine. Better than fine — with a bit of luck Maxis Realtor should be Richter’s-free by the end of the quarter. Then I’1l1 join... No, no sign [yet —]
FX: HE’S INTERRUPTED BY SOUND OF TARDIS LANDING 20 FEET AWAY.
Wait. Hold on, I’1l1 call you back. It’s her, I think it’s her!
FX: HE ENDS COMMUNICATION AS TARDIS FINISHES LANDING.
(GOING OVER TO TARDIS) Hello? .. Mother?
FX: TARDIS DOOR OPENS.
Hello, Adric.
Doctor? What’s going on? Where’s my mother? Where’s Nyssa?
FX: CLOSING TARDIS DOOR.
Ah. Yes. That’s why I’ve come here. To tell you in person. Thought it was only right.
She’s not with you...? What’s happened to her? Where is she?
There’s no easy way to say this. I’m afraid... I’m afraid you’re never going to see your mother again.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 3
What?
She — I mean, we; I mean, she —
Just tell me. Is she dead?
No, no. She’s alive, I can assure you of that much.
Then where is she?
Nyssa is.. somewhere beyond even the TARDIS’s reach.
What’s that supposed to mean? You’ve lost her?
Not lost, exactly. A set of circumstances forced us into a situation — [where]
My mother said she would come straight here. She promised, one month ago, back on Valderon.
I know, yes. But the TARDIS was diverted. Into E-Space.
(DISBELIEF) E-Space?
Another universe. Linked to this one by —
I know what it is, it’s where my namesake came from. So my mother is still in this other universe?
. Yes.
(FURIOUS) So why can’t you just go back and get her?
It’s not quite as simple as that.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 4
You managed it before, why can’t you do it again?
There is no way back. The CVE, the link between that universe and this, has been sealed shut.
Then re-open it!
Even if that were possible, in an infinite multitude of universes, we’d never find the right one. I’m sorry.
Sorry? Is that all you can say? You tell me I’m never going to see my mother again and all you can do is stand there and make excuses?
I’m not making excuses. I take full responsibility. If anyone is to blame for what happened, it’s me.
So what did happen?
It’s a long story.
Then the sooner you start, Doctor, the better.

Yes, good point. Very well. After we were diverted into E- Space, we needed to find a way back through another CVE. But then Tegan suffered the indignity of being kidnapped by a gang of space pirates...
FX: REVERSE ECHO INTO:
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 5
SCENE 2. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
FX: TIME ROTOR SLOWING.
Why are we stopping?
Because the Doctor’s found her.
Already?
Residual energy trace from the surface of Isenfel, it wasn’t too hard.
FX: SCANNER.
Tegan’s on board that ship?
Giving her captors a piece of her mind, no doubt.
Can we materialise on board?
We can try.
FX: OPERATES CONTROLS.
They’re heading to another solar system. One of the few solar systems.
(CHECKING READINGS) The third planet is in a temperate orbit. Presumably that’s their destination.
Presumably. — Locking on co-ordinates... now.
FX: TARDIS LURCHES TERRIBLY. VIBRATION ON VOICES FROM NOW ON.
What is it? What’s happening?
(FX: OPERATING CONTROLS) Not sure. Power loss. As though something is siphoning energy from the TARDIS.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 6
Something? The spaceship?
FX: B/G TARDIS HUM DROPPING IN PITCH.
No. Something down there, on the third planet.
FX: TARDIS LURCHES AND MAKES ALARMING NOISES FROM NOW ON.
Doctor, the energy drain. It’s increasing.
Almost fifty per cent gone already. Fifty-five. Sixty!
What happens if we run out of power?
Newton’s first law. We’ll keep on drifting through space until we hit something.
Except with no life support, we’ll either suffocate or freeze to death first.
Always looking for a silver lining, aren’t you, Turlough?
Energy levels now down to twenty per cent.
No choice. We’ll have to perform an emergency materialisation.
Doctor, the spaceship! I think it’s experiencing the same effect.
(PREOCCUPIED) What?
Its navigation lights are flashing and it’s descending towards the planet.
Nothing we can do for them, I’m afraid.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 7
But without any power they’1ll crash. And Tegan’s on board!
I do realise that. But we have our own problems to worry about.
Five percent.
FX: CLOISTER BELL.
Activating emergency storage cells. Fingers crossed...
FX: BUTTONS PRESSED, TARDIS WHEEZES TERRIBLY, SHUDDERS.
There’s not enough power, we’re not going to make it!
Come on, old girl. One final push!
The spaceship, it’s entered the planet’s atmosphere. It’s
burning up. Tegan!
Have to divert every remaining ounce of energy...
FX: TARDIS WHEEZES AGAIN AND STARTS LANDING.
You did it. We’re landing.
In the very loosest sense. Hold on tight!
FX: TARDIS CRASH LANDS. CONTINUES INTO:
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 8
SCENE 3. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM. [CONTINUOUS]
ENDS. B/G CONTROL ROOM HUM FADES OUT FROM NOW ON.
Everyone alright?
I’m fine. Nyssa?
Yes. It’s Tegan I’m more worried about. What happened to the spaceship?
FX: DOCTOR OPERATES CONTROLS, POWER FAILS ON THEM AS HE DOES
SO, WE HEAR BUTTONS AND SWITCHES CLICKING.
I don’t know. The console is... dead.
Dead?
There’s no power for the instruments. Nothing.
And the scanner’s blank.
FX: LIGHTS GOING OUT SOUND EFFECT — SEE ‘DEATH TO THE DALEKS’.
If that wasn’t bad enough, there go the lights!
FX: TARDIS NOW SILENT. CHURCH ECHO ON VOICES AND FOOTSTEPS.
But we did land, didn’t we?
As far as I can tell. We’re somewhere on that planet. But what it’s like — well, there’s only one way to find out.
Go outside.
Yes.
But we don’t even know if it has a breathable atmosphere.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 9
Then I suggest we open the doors very slowly and carefully.
And how do we do that with no power?
We take the manual approach. (REACHES UNDER CONSOLE) I remember stowing a crank handle under the console, just in case...
Doctor, you don’t seem very concerned about Tegan.
(FX: FIXES CRANK IN DOOR, TURNING IT AS HE SPEAKS) We made it down in one piece, maybe she did too.
And then what? With the TARDIS out of action, we’re trapped here. We have no way of leaving this world, never mind this universe.
(TURNING HANDLE) One thing at a time, eh, Turlough?
FX: TARDIS DOORS OPEN. JANISSARY/INDIAN CARNIVAL MUSIC OUTSIDE
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 10
SCENE 4: EXT. MARKETPLACE.
FX: DISTANT CARNIVAL MUSIC.
(NARRATION)

We emerged into an alleyway of a shanty town. The buildings were made of stone with roofs of corrugated iron, and decorated with spray-painted murals and wooden carvings. Everything was bathed in the sickly glow of a red sun hanging low in the sky.
FX: INTO STORY. DOCTOR, NYSSA AND TURLOUGH APPROACHING.
At least the air is breathable, even if it smells of smoke and corroded fuel cells. And, ugh. Rotten food.
The music’s coming from down there. Looks like quite a crowd has gathered.
Some sort of marketplace? Or a fairground?
FX: THEY APPROACH MARKETPLACE, MOVING AMONGST VENDORS, SOME
ALIEN-VOICED. VARIOUS LANGUAGES, INCLUDING IN ENGLISH:
#1: Roasted critch-nuts, two creds a scrape. Roasted critch-nuts...
#2: All the finest pole-skins and weave, get your pole-skins here.
#3: Valto fruit, minnow-whites, bittermeats and protein bakes...
#4: Fortune charms and poultices, amulets and talismans...
#5: Spacesuits, oxygen condensers, atmospheric filters...
Extraordinary. There must be over a dozen different species.
At least, not including us.
A technologically advanced civilisation, but materially impoverished.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 11
Have you noticed something else? The illuminations.
Paper lanterns and oil lamps.
No electrical power. These people are suffering the same energy drain that we experienced.
You mean, electricity doesn’t work here?
Apparently not. So they’ve had to get back to basics.
FX: THEY APPROACH FESTIVITIES, MUSIC LOUDER. DANCING.
Makes you wonder what they have to celebrate.
Maybe they don’t need an excuse. Maybe they need a distraction.
The costumes, they’re like skeletons with skulls for masks.
Yes. A memento mori? Or a means to commune with ancestors, like New Orleans’ Day of the Dead.
(APPROACHING THROUGH CROWD) Pretty girl, you wanna dance?
I’m sorry —
You dance, with me, have fun?
I’m not really in the mood, but thank you. Tell me, what are you celebrating?
You don’t know?
No. We’ve only just arrived. So what are you celebrating?
(LAUGHS) The end, isn’t it!
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 12
The end of what?
Of everything, my friend! The lights are going out, out, out!
Yes, we've noticed, we had similar trouble when we landed —
Every night, stars in the sky, fewer than the night before. That’s why we come to Apollyon, for the carnival of death. You sure you don’t wanna dance, pretty girl?
Yes, quite sure.
(LEAVING) If you say-so, bye-bye. Don’t let the Sandmen touch you!
FX: HE REJOINS THE DANCE. OUR HEROES MOVE THROUGH MARKET.
They’re celebrating the end of the universe. Well, I suppose it makes sense to have fun while you still can.
“Enjoy yourself, it’s later than you think.” Odd thing, this universe should have centuries left, but the way he was talking, you’d think it was only a matter of days.
He said the stars were going out. Maybe it is.
So they’ve all come here to Apollyon. The land of the dead. Refugees from every corner of E-Space congregating for one final knees-up — (REACTS) Get down!
FX: A SPACESHIP ROARS OVERHEAD, DEAFENING. REVELLERS REACT.
It’s going to crash!
No, it’s fired its retro-rockets. Just in time.
FX: SPACESHIP ROARS AWAY INTO DISTANCE, ENGINES THUNDERING.
I thought there was supposed to be no power here.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 13
That ship was venting fuel to slow its descent. It would only do that if it was under manual control.
It came down somewhere over there, behind those watch-towers. Doctor. If that spaceship managed to land —
- then maybe Tegan’s did too, exactly!
FX: THEY HEAD OFF. CROSSFADE TO:
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 14
SCENE 5. EXT. LANDING AREA.
FX: SPACESHIP HYDRAULICS HISSING, ENGINES POWERING DOWN.
(APPROACHING, LOUD WHISPER) It’s a spaceship graveyard!
Doctor, over there! That’s the ship that Tegan was on.
You’re right. Looks like they managed a soft landing.
FX: HEAVING, HEAVY WOODEN PLANKS CREAKING, CHAINS CLANKING.
TRACK OF SHOUTS OF ‘OVER HERE’, ‘THIS WAY’.
Only by using the landing gear as shock-absorbers. It’1ll never take off again. No wonder they’re hauling it away for scrap.
What?
Over there. They’re preparing some sort of winching mechanism.
A treadwheel crane and lifting tower. I haven’t seen anything like it since the early middle ages.
Presumably the only technology that still works —
(WHISPER) Keep your head down, or they’1l see us!
FX: IN THE DISTANCE, TEGAN IS BEING LED OFF A SHIP BY BRANARACK
AND SEVERAL OTHER PIRATES.
You could at least lend me a coat, it’s brass monkeys out here!
Cease your whining!
Don’t you tell me to shut up, you overdressed Neanderthal!
AMUSEMENT
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 15
(LAUGHS) Oh, the damsel is full of fighting spirit. Just what we need!
You just wait, Long John Silver, I'll show you fighting spirit, right where it hurts!
(LAUGHS) Promises, promises! Alright, lads, bring her along! And try not to damage her too much, she’s our ticket out of here!
FX: TEGAN HAULED AWAY BY AMUSED PIRATES.
They’ve got Tegan.
Yes. I’m not sure who to feel sorry for most.
There’s too many of them for us to take on.
Not to mention the fact that they’re armed with muskets. We’1l just have to follow and see where they’re taking her. Come on!
FX: THEY FOLLOW. CROSSFADE TO:
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 16
SCENE 6. EXT. CITADEL GATES.
FX: WALKING THROUGH TOWN UNDER THE FOLLOWING:
(NARRATION)

We followed Tegan and her abductors through the winding streets, following the bobbing glow of their oil lamps, taking care to remain out of sight. After half an hour we came to the ruins of an ancient castle. A high metal fence topped with barbed wire surrounded the crumbling remains. The only way in was through an iron doorway guarded by two robots resembling medieval suits of armour.
FX: ROBOT SENTINELS ARE STEAM-DRIVEN SO HISS, CHUG AND CLANK.
Only those with a tribute may enter.
This wench is my tribute.
(STRUGGLING) No I’m not. Whatever it is, I have nothing to do with this.
FX: SENTINEL CLANKS, INSPECTING HER.
The tribute is satisfactory. You may enter.
FX: DOORWAY OPENS.
There you are, lads, told you it’d work. In we go.
FX: SENTINEL CLANKS.
Only one may enter with the tribute. No other.
No need to get all steamed up. — Alright lads, you heard our tinpot friend. You wait back at the Buccaneer, I’1l sort everything.
(PROTESTS) Come off it, Cap’n Branarack! / You expect us to trust you? [ETC]
I can hardly leave without you, can I? Not that the thought would even cross my mind. I won’t be long. Captain’s honour!
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 17
(RESIGNED CUSSING AS THEY DEPART) Alright, alright! / We’1l trust ye, fools that we are...!
FX: DURING NEXT 4 LINES, WE SHIFT TO VANTAGE POINT IN CROWD.
Come on, wench.
You'd better hope you’re not within kicking distance when I get out of these chains.
You ain’t getting out of those chains, not for the foreseeable. Now move!
(PROTESTING) Hey!
FX: HE DRAGS TEGAN AWAY. DOOR CLOSES.
I wonder what’s in there they’re so keen to protect.
I assume we’re going to go in and find out.
We have to get past those robots first.
Well, we could try asking them nicely.
FX: THEY APPROACH.
How can robots even function, without electricity?
Through a combination of steam and clockwork, apparently. Rather impressive, don’t you think?
Access to the citadel is restricted. Only those with a tribute my enter.
And if I don’t have a tribute, I can’t come in?
Only those with a tribute may enter.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 18
(TO SENTINEL) I am the Doctor’s tribute.
(WHISPER) Nyssa!
FX: SENTINEL CLANKS, INSPECTING HER.
The tribute is satisfactory. You may enter.
FX: DOOR OPENS.
Thank you. Just straight on down the passage, is it? Come on Nyssa, Turlough.
FX: SENTINEL CLANKS.
Only one may enter with the tribute. No other.
Ah. Turlough, would you like to go back to the TARDIS and wait for us there?
Not particularly, no.
I thought as much. (TO SENTINEL) Hello! Turlough here is my tribute too.
What?
Only one tribute is required.
But is there any rule saying I can’t have more? Consider it a goodwill gesture. A free gift!
You may enter with your two tributes.
Thank you, most kind.
FX: DOOR CLOSES BEHIND THEM WITH ECHOING SLAM.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 19
SCENE 7. INT. PRISON.
FX: MOANING PRISONERS OCCASIONALLY RATTLING METAL CUPS ON BARS.
CLANKING ABOUT — LIKE NUTS AND BOLTS FACTORY.
(NARRATION) We found ourselves in a long antechamber that stank of damp
straw. It was lit with flaming torches and lined with metal cages, each containing several captives in dirty rags.
Wait here with your tributes.
What? But I want to see whoever’s in charge.
You will. But first you must wait.
And I presume any attempt to resist will be punished?
FX: SENTINEL CLANKS.
Any attempt to resist will be terminal. Enter the cage.
But we’re looking for someone, a friend of ours called [Tegan]
Enter the cage!
I think we’d better do as it says.
FX: THEY ENTER. STRAW-COVERED FLOOR.
I’m beginning to think that this wasn’t a very clever idea.
FX: CAGE DOOR SLAMS AND LOCKS, CLANKING. SENTINEL STOMPS OFF.
Charming. It could at least have offered us a cup of tea.
I can’t see Tegan anywhere, can you?
No. Although it appears we have a cell-mate.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 20
(STIRS) You are looking for the woman who just came in?
Yes, did you see her?
She was taken to be prepared.
Prepared for what? Oh no, let me guess. Sacrifice.
That’s what we’re here for. Some of us are volunteers. But most of us were dragged off the streets and brought here to die.
But why? What are these sacrifices for?
We are the price that must be paid for freedom. We die so that others can live. I’m sorry. You will not see your friend again.
Oh, I wouldn’t be so sure of that. Turlough, keep an eye out for our steam-driven jailer, could you?
FX: HISSING, GURGLING OFF.
It seems to be busy re-filling itself with coal and water.
Good. Nyssa, what do you make of the lock?
Rusty, nearly corroded solid, of a rudimentary design. (FX:
PICKING LOCK) I should be able to unpick it with my brooch. Adric once showed me how.
You think you can get free?
Given time, I don’t see why not... Sorry. We haven’t been introduced. I’m the Doctor, this is Turlough —
Hello.
- and my friend unpicking the lock is Nyssa.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 21
My name is Cherryanne.
Delighted to share a cage with you, Cherryanne. Well, not delighted, but you know what I mean. You’re not from this world, are you?

No, my brother and I are from Bellezar. Our village sold all their belongings to secure us passage on a freight ship. For two months we were kept in the hold, huddling in the cold and dark with a dozen others from our world, half-expecting to be ejected into space at any instant.
But you were brought here safely?
The ship crashed, killing the crew and most of the passengers. My brother and I, and a few others, survived and fled into the settlement, where we begged for food and shelter.
So how did you end up here?
Two days ago, I was kidnapped by a riot gang. My brother... I don’t know if he’s alive or dead.
But why come to Apollyon? Why leave Bellezar?
Because of the great darkness spreading across the heavens. The hungry night. We knew it would consume our planet, and had heard tell of a way out, a gateway to another universe.
A CVE! There’s a CVE somewhere on this planet.
Yes. It would explain a great deal.
I saw our home star fade away in a matter of seconds. Everyone on Bellezar, all those people...
I’m very sorry.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 22
And so am I. My world met a similar fate. Doctor. I’ve unlocked
the door.
FX: CAGE OPENS. CONTINUES INTO:
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 23
SCENE 8. INT. PRISON. [CONTINUOUS]
FX: THEY EMERGE FROM CAGE.
Cherryanne, do you know where they would have taken Tegan to be ‘prepared’ ?
I don’t, the sentinels took her. I —
Alert. A holding-cage has been unsecured. Alert!
FX: DURING THIS, AN ALARM SOUNDS — A CLANGING BELL, LIKE ON AN
TRAIN.
That didn’t take them long. Nyssa, take Cherryanne, find a way out.
But Doctor —
I’ll find you, just get yourselves to safety. Go!
Very well. Goodbye, Doctor, Turlough.
FX: NYSSA AND CHERRYANNE RUN.
Shouldn’t we run too?
Not if we want to find Tegan.
FX: SENTINEL APPROACHES THEM.
Halt. Do not move.
Don’t worry, we’re not going anywhere.
FX: SENTINEL HALTS.
Why did you interfere with the holding-cage?
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 24
To get your attention. You see, my tribute and I, we’re in rather a hurry, and we don’t appreciate being kept waiting.
Or being treated like common thieves.
So if you could just take us to whoever’s in charge, that would be super.
FX: SENTINEL CLANKS.
Your request is granted. You are to be granted an audience with Science-tech Pallister.
Excellent. Lead on, Macduff.
FX: SENTINEL STARTS MOVING. THEY FOLLOW. CROSSFADE TO:
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 25
SCENE 9. INT. PALLISTER’S CONTROL ROOM [FEW MINUTES LATER]
FX: FADE UP. BUBBLING FLASKS, STEAM ENGINES, FRANKENSTEIN’S
LABORATORY. DOOR OPENS, DOCTOR AND TURLOUGH LED IN BY SENTINEL.
Ah. So you’re the one who broke from one of my cages.
You will have to forgive our impatience.
And this is your tribute? — What is he, ex-Terran?
Do you know, I’m not entirely sure.
This is hardly the time —
FX: SENTINEL CLANKS.
Physiology approximates to ex-Terran. Life force register nine.
Nine? Yes, yes, that will be most satisfactory.
Satisfactory for what?
Sorry, why would you offer a tribute if you didn’t know?
Turlough isn’t a tribute. We’ve come to offer you our help.
You’re a science-tech? Speciality?
Oh, practically everything. People call me the Doctor.
And what makes you think I need your help?
This laboratory of yours is extraordinary. All based around non-electrical technology. You even have a computer, after a fashion. A difference engine! Babbage never could get his to work.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 26
Who is this ‘Babbage’?
And these robots are your creations, I assume?
The sentinels, yes. Designed and built by my hand.
Most ingenious. An inspired piece of engineering.
You are too kind, Doctor.
I could suggest a few improvements, of course, but we’1l save that for later. I’m rather more interested in how you’ve managed to open a gateway to another universe.
You mean, the portal? Oh, I didn’t open it, Doctor. It’s always been present on this world, in one form or another.
It’s the reason why electricity doesn’t work here?
Of course. Any energy on this planet is drained through the portal like water down a plughole.
But it’s not merely drawing energy from this world. It’s drawing it from this entire universe.
Indeed, indeed. According to my observations, we’re experiencing both dimensional contraction and heat death.
A simultaneous big crunch and big freeze.
So what are you trying to do? Close the CVE?
Of course not, that would be quite, quite futile. No. I’m trying to open it.
LINKING MUSIC
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 27
SCENE 10. EXT. PORTAL [FEW MINUTES LATER]
FX: FADE UP. THE PORTAL THROBS AND CRACKLES, PLUS CONSTANT
ROAR, BUT WITH SPACEY EFFECTS. PALLISTER WALKS UP,
BY DOCTOR AND TURLOUGH.
Behold. The portal.
(NARRATION)

It was a whirlpool, a swirling vortex suspended above the flagstones of an ancient courtyard. Viewed from the front was like looking down Niagara Falls; viewed from the side, it was two-dimensional, like an image on a cinema screen. In front of the portal was a structure made of wooden scaffolding, comprising of a railway track ending in a wooden ramp pivoted at one end like a drawbridge.
The citadel was built around this and other such portals, but now this is all that remains. Given sufficient energy, it can be temporarily stabilised to permit egress.
But how can a spaceship fly through there, with no power?
The ship is winched up those tracks; then, once it’s in position, the ramp is tilted so it can descend into the maelstrom.
And return to N-Space.
In the vicinity of a G-type star, where it can refuel its solar cells. Not exactly high-tech, but it works.
But the portal can only be stabilised temporarily?
The interface between the universes is weakening, growing ever- more unstable.
Yes, it would. The two universes are pulling apart.
But if the portal is constantly draining any energy source, how can you stabilise it?
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 28
FX: SENTINEL CLANKS UP TO HIM. FOLLOWED BY BRANARACK.
Pallister. This human wishes to speak to you.
Aye, so I do.
Ah, Captain Branarack. — Doctor, Turlough, if you’1ll excuse me.
Not at all.
Sentinel one, make sure they don’t accidentally wander off.
As commanded.
(QUIET) Doctor, that’s the man we saw —
(QUIET) Yes, so Tegan can’t be far away.
So, Captain, is your tribute prepared?
I’ve strapped her in the induction chamber, as requested. She put up quite a struggle. Gave me a few bruises!
Full of life, that’s what I like to hear. Very well. If you’d like to return to your ship, I’1ll have it brought to the portal.
It’s already loaded onto the tracks and connected to the
winching-chain. My crew are onboard.
Excellent. Once you’ve rejoined them, I’1l be in radio contact.
Ha! The sooner I’m rid of this benighted universe, the better.
FX: BRANARACK LEAVES.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 29
So that’s what the tributes are for. To provide the energy to stabilise the portal so a ship can pass through.
There is a great deal of energy contained within the molecular bonds of all living tissue. It is simply a matter of drawing it out, by a process of magnetic induction.
Using human beings as chemical batteries.
It’s obscene.
It’s a matter of necessity. We are no longer in a position to afford moral luxuries. How else are we to escape the death of this universe? Perhaps you would care for a demonstration?
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 30
SCENE 11. INT. POWER VAULT [FEW MOMENTS LATER]
FX: CRACKLE OF STATIC, RUMBLE OF IMMENSE POWER. DOCTOR AND CO
ACCOMPANIED BY CLANKING SENTINELS.
(NARRATION)

He led us into a vaulted chamber, like the nave of a cathedral. But instead of an altar there was an alcove, made of wire mesh and surrounded by heavy-duty power cables. And in that alcove, manacled by her wrists, was Tegan!
Doctor! Turlough! About time you turned up!
Delighted to see you too. You haven’t been harmed?
Apart from being trussed up in this thing, never better.

DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 10. EXT. PORTAL [FEW MINUTES LATER]
WATERFALL: ROAR, BUT WITH SPACEY EFFECTS. PALLISTER WALKS UP,
FOLLOWED: BY DOCTOR AND TURLOUGH.

DOCTOR: It was a whirlpool, a swirling vortex suspended above the flagstones of an ancient courtyard. Viewed from the front was like looking down Niagara Falls; viewed from the side, it was two-dimensional, like an image on a cinema screen. In front of the portal was a structure made of wooden scaffolding, comprising of a railway track ending in a wooden ramp pivoted at one end like a drawbridge.

PALLISTER: In the vicinity of a G-type star, where it can refuel its solar cells. Not exactly high-tech, but it works.

SENTINEL: Pallister. This human wishes to speak to you.
BRANARACK: Aye, so I do.
PALLISTER: Ah, Captain Branarack. — Doctor, Turlough, if you’1ll excuse me.
DOCTOR: Not at all.
PALLISTER: Sentinel one, make sure they don’t accidentally wander off.
SENTINEL: As commanded.
TURLOUGH: (QUIET) Doctor, that’s the man we saw —

PALLISTER: So, Captain, is your tribute prepared?
BRANARACK: I’ve strapped her in the induction chamber, as requested. She put up quite a struggle. Gave me a few bruises!
PALLISTER: Full of life, that’s what I like to hear. Very well. If you’d like to return to your ship, I’1ll have it brought to the portal.
BRANARACK: It’s already loaded onto the tracks and connected to the
BRANARACK: winching-chain. My crew are onboard.

BRANARACK: Ha! The sooner I’m rid of this benighted universe, the better.

DOCTOR: So that’s what the tributes are for. To provide the energy to stabilise the portal so a ship can pass through.
PALLISTER: There is a great deal of energy contained within the molecular bonds of all living tissue. It is simply a matter of drawing it out, by a process of magnetic induction.
DOCTOR: Using human beings as chemical batteries.
TURLOUGH: It’s obscene.
PALLISTER: It’s a matter of necessity. We are no longer in a position to afford moral luxuries. How else are we to escape the death of this universe? Perhaps you would care for a demonstration?
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 30
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 11. INT. POWER VAULT [FEW MOMENTS LATER]
LED: ACCOMPANIED BY CLANKING SENTINELS.
DOCTOR: (NARRATION)
DOCTOR: He led us into a vaulted chamber, like the nave of a cathedral. But instead of an altar there was an alcove, made of wire mesh and surrounded by heavy-duty power cables. And in that alcove, manacled by her wrists, was Tegan!
TEGAN: Doctor! Turlough! About time you turned up!

TEGAN: Apart from being trussed up in this thing, never better.
PALLISTER: You know this... female?
TURLOUGH: She’s an old friend.
PALLISTER: Oh dear, that is inconvenient. You have my sincere condolences.
DOCTOR: What?
TURLOUGH: You have to get her out of there!
PALLISTER: She’s Captain Branarack’s tribute, and I fear that upsetting him would be more than my life’s worth.
TURLOUGH: But you can’t kill an innocent person.
PALLISTER: Unless you can provide a replacement, I don’t have a great deal of choice. Sentinels one and two —
DOCTOR: Please, you needn’t arrest us.
PALLISTER: Stand by. Break them both if they try to interfere.
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 31
SENTINELS: As commanded.
PALLISTER: Science-tech Pallister calling the Buccaneer. Are you receiving me?
BRANARACK: (DISTORT) Buccaneer receiving, not very loud and not very clear.
PALLISTER: All set for egress?
BRANARACK: (DISTORT) - just get on with it, you blithering dolt!
PALLISTER: Very good. Stand by. Activating winch.
DOCTOR: Pallister. Listen. There has to be another means of generating power.
PALLISTER: (ADJUSTING MACHINES) I’m afraid not. Only organic tissue is a viable energy source. I wish there was some other way, but my hands are tied.
TEGAN: Your hands are tied? What about mine?
PALLISTER: I’m sorry. Your life — or rather, your death — will enable others to escape the collapse of this universe.
TURLOUGH: Doctor. Look.
DOCTOR: (NARRATION)
DOCTOR: Outside, the pirate’s spaceship was being winched up a funicular railway laid through the terraced gardens of the citadel. I looked out at the overgrown gardens, at the stone balustrades and the eroded, moss-covered sculptures of lions and ancient knights. And then I realised.
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 32
DOCTOR: I've been here before.
TURLOUGH: What?
DOCTOR: This castle. I’ve walked in its grounds.
TURLOUGH: When?
DOCTOR: In my previous incarnation. It was on the other side of the gateway.
TEGAN: How does that help us?
DOCTOR: (REALISING) Of course. The vastly accelerated rate of decay. This universe should have hundreds of years left if the CVE remained a constant size.
TURLOUGH: But whenever the CVE is stabilised and forced open wider —
DOCTOR: It hastens the process. And brings forward the day of reckoning!
PALLISTER: What does it matter? All we can do is to try to save as many as we can. Ship in position. Elevating platform.
DOCTOR: (NARRATION)
DOCTOR: Outside, the ramp beneath the pirate’s spaceship lifted off the ground and began to tilt down towards the portal.
PALLISTER: Calling Buccaneer. — Good fortune, Captain. See you on the other side.
TEGAN: Doctor, help me!
DOCTOR: Pallister. Stop. You’re making a terrible mistake!
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 33
PALLISTER: Too late, Doctor. But don’t worry. The process is very swift.
DOCTOR: (NARRATION) Pallister pulled the lever, and the alcove containing Tegan began to flicker with forks of blue lightning.
TEGAN: Doctor... please! Do something!
DOCTOR: (NARRATION)
DOCTOR: Meanwhile outside, the dimensional portal expanded until it was over forty feet high. And within, the whirlpool was replaced by the sight of a galaxy full of stars. The universe of N-Space.
PALLISTER: Releasing winch-locks. (FX: LEVER PULLED)
DOCTOR: (NARRATION) And slowly but surely the spacecraft slid down the ramp towards
DOCTOR: the portal...
TEGAN: END OF PART ONE

SCENE 12. INT. ADRIC’S HOUSE.
FX: TARDIS DOOR OPENS.
Doctor?
Ah, Tegan, feeling any better?
A little. (SEES ADRIC) Adric.

Tegan and Turlough have been in a state of induced d-sleep, to help them recover.

That he won’t be seeing her again? Yes.

The Doctor was in the process of telling me.
I’d just got to the point where you were strapped into the induction chamber, do you remember?
I’m hardly likely to forget.

Not particularly.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 35
Good. I’1ll be back in a minute.
FX: DOCTOR ENTERS TARDIS.
I’m sorry, Adric. Nyssa loved you so much, you know.

That wasn’t her fault, that was...
The Doctor’s?

I don’t know what to think. I’ve only just woken up.

SCENE 13. INT. POWER VAULT.
FX: SUDDEN POWER FAILURE, PLUG PULLED, STEAM ENGINES HAYWIRE.
(PULLING LEVERS) Magnetic induction failure. Power outage. This can’t be happening!
It seems your machine isn’t quite as reliable as you thought, Pallister.
(ALARM) I suggest you take a look outside, both of you.
What? (SEES) The portal! It’s contracting! Destabilising!
And that spaceship’s still heading right for it.
I doubt Captain Branarack is going to be too pleased when it’s torn to pieces.
I must raise the platform. Halt the descent!
FX: HEAVY CLANKING, CRUNCHING GEARS. STEAM.
(RELAXES) Done it.
With only a few feet to spare.
FX: RADIO.
(DISTORT) Pallister! What in the name of the seven ice-moons of Parthenon do you think you’re playing at?

(DISTORT) ‘A minor malfunction’? We were nearly hurled into the jaws of doom just as they were snapping shut!
My apologies, I’1ll investigate the problem right away...
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 37
(DISTORT) First of all you’1ll bring the Buccaneer level, I don’t trust this contraption of yours —
Yes, of course. Lowering platform.
FX: LEVERS, CLANKING. MACHINE POWERS DOWN.
(DISTORT) And you'd better get things working again, because the last person who failed me, ended up with —
FX: PALLISTER SWITCHES OFF RADIO.
Yes, I’m sure they did.
Any chance one of you could get me out of this thing?
(SEEING HER) Alive and healthy, good, good. Save us having to find another tribute.
The offer is still open, you know. My friend and I can help.
Help? What with?
Well, for a start, getting your machine working again.
For all I know, you were the ones who sabotaged it.
How could we have done that? We’ve been with you the whole time.

Very well. But any hint of treachery, and I’1ll have her killed.
Doctor, you’re not agreeing to co-operate with this lunatic?
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 38
I don’t see that we have any choice, if we’re going to save your life and stand any sort of chance of getting home.
Alright. So, which of you’s going to let me out of here?
Ah, not just yet. You can remain here.
What? Doctor, tell him —
Sorry, Tegan. We’ll be back as soon as possible.
Turlough!
The Doctor’s right. You might as well get comfortable.
Comfortable he says! Trussed up like a chicken...
Sentinel one, come with us. Sentinel two. Wait here with the woman. Make sure no-one else comes near, understand?
FX: SENTINEL CLANKS.
Good. Doctor, Turlough. The power generator is in the vault
directly beneath here, if you’d like to follow me.
(AS THEY GO) Only too delighted.
FX: SENTINEL LEAVES WITH DOCTOR, TURLOUGH AND CO DURING THIS.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 39
SCENE 14. INT. POWER VAULT [CONTINUOUS]
Great. The boys get to go and play with their toys while muggins here gets left behind. Chained to a griddle with nothing but a suit of armour for company.
FX: SENTINEL CLANKS.
Don’t talk much, do you?
FX: SENTINEL CLANKS, APPROACHES.
Hey, what do you want.. keep back!
FX: CLANK! CLANK! CLANK!. THEN SENTINEL HALTS. HEAD UNSCREWED.

You know Nyssa?
She was the one who cut the power.
While you sneaked in here disguised as a robot?
Nyssa and I overpowered one of the sentinels and removed its workings. Well, Nyssa did most of the work. I’ve come to rescue you. If you’ll hold still...
FX: TEGAN’S MANACLES UNDONE, SHE STUMBLES FORWARD.
(RELIEF) Thank you, much appreciated. So where is Nyssa now?

LINKING MUSIC

FX: FADE UP. PRISON AMBIENCE AUDIBLE. SENTINEL CLANKS TOWARDS
US.

(EMERGING FROM HIDING) Tegan! You’re unharmed! (HUG)
Just about. Apparently I have you to thank for saving my life.
We knew you would be the next ‘tribute’ so, while Cherryanne went to find you, I went to the vault containing Pallister’s power generator and, well, sabotaged it.

Oh no.

Well, with a ‘sentinel’ to lead the way, hopefully that shouldn’t be too difficult.

(MUFFLED) I’ll give it my best shot. Walk ahead of me, I’1l try to look like I’m pushing you.

FX: WIND WHIPPING TARPAULIN ROOFS. THUNDER. TORRENTIAL RAIN.
(NARRATION)

We made it out of the citadel easy enough, emerging into a icy, windy night. Once we were in the clear, Cherryanne removed her armour and hid it in a rubbish tip. Then she led us through the gaslit streets to her home, a small wooden hut with a tarpaulin roof.
FX: RUSTY DOOR SQUEAKS AS CHERRYANNE, TEGAN AND NYSSA ENTER

SCENE 17. INT. CHERRYANNE’S HUT [CONTINUOUS]
FX: DOOR SHUTS BEHIND CHERRYANNE, TEGAN & NYSSA.
(NARRATION) Inside, a frail figure lay on a mattress on the floor.
This is my brother, Raldarin.
Cherry — who are these?
Friends. This is Tegan, and Nyssa.
TEGAN/NYSSA Hello./Hello.

I dreamt of Bellezar. So far away, but getting nearer.

FX: RALDARIN HUDDLES HIMSELF IN BED. CHERRYANNE BUSYING HERSELF

IN B/G, SNORING GENTLY, NOT TOO DISTRACTING!
I’m young, I’1l be fine.
You’re not as young as you look. Speaking of which. Cherryanne, I don’t mean to talk out of turn, but this guy is your brother?
Yes —

What? Then what happened to him?
He was infected. With the entropy plague.
The entropy plague?
The blight of this universe. On some worlds it is called ‘the Dusty Death’. On others it is known as ‘The Wasting’.
And it makes people older?
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 46
It makes them decay. The process of ageing accelerated. Their skin grows dry and wrinkled. Their limbs become thin and weak. And then... well, just look at my brother’s left hand.
It’s cracked, like a mud-lake during a drought. (DISMAY) And he’s lost two fingers.

Oh no.
His hand was the first part of him to be affected, before it spread to the rest of his body. (SUDDEN) Don’t get too close —

I don’t know whether it’s true, but some people believe it is transmitted through touch.
Is there a cure? There must be a cure? Nyssa?
No. I don’t — I don’t think there’s anything anyone can do.
What? That doesn’t sound like you.
Don’t you remember, Tegan? You’ve seen this before. You told me. This is what happened to the Monitor on Logopolis.
(REMEMBERS) Oh no. Entropy.
And now the same thing’s happening here, to this whole universe. The same thing that destroyed Traken. Tegan. This is how my people died.
The Doctor said something about the CVE. About how it was causing all this.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 47
Yes. It’s draining all the energy, all the binding structure from this universe.

And denied medical treatment?

It’s barbaric.

I recall things weren’t so different on your world, when we visited it during the time of plague. And I’ve seen similar reactions to Lazar’s disease and Richter’s. Fear of disease can lead people to do terrible, desperate things. Things worse than the disease itself.
Whenever a new spaceship arrives, Pallister has his sentinels check it for any signs of infection. If they find any, he’1l have the ship incinerated with everyone onboard.
But you avoided that, because your ship crashed.
If my brother was infected, we didn’t know about it, he didn’t show any of the signs till later. He didn’t bring it here.
If it’s as widespread as you say, it doesn’t matter how it got here. What matters is to prevent further infection, and to care for the infected.
You haven’t changed, have you, Nyssa? After all these years, you’re still putting other people first — and yourself last.
It’s how I was brought up. And I wouldn’t want to be any other way.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 48

FX: FADE UP. SIMILAR ATMOS TO CARNIVAL. BUSTLING MARKET,

. What are we going to buy stuff with? We haven’t any money.

FX: LOW RUMBLING, WHOOSHING OF WIND BEGINS FROM HERE.

SUDDEN PANIC

Nyssa!
FX: EARTHQUAKE STOPS, CALM RESUMES.
/CUSTOMERS :
CALMING, RETURNING TO THEIR BUSINESS

it

FX: THEY HEAD OFF.

SCENE 19. INT. MEDICAL CENTRE [FEW MINUTES LATER]
FX: FADE UP. A REFUGEE CRISIS. CLAMOUR, CHATTER, A CRYING BABY,

(NARRATION)
The medical centre was little more than a tent, heaving with refugees of every race and species. A queue snaked towards a row of tables, while the steam-driven robots stood guard.

FX: REFUGEE HEADS OFF THROUGH CROWD DURING THIS.

THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 53
Just some — (SEES SOMETHING) What on Earth!
Tegan?
Over there. The Doctor!
(NARRATION)
The Doctor was at the far end of the tent with ‘Science-Tech’ Pallister, who seemed to be giving him a guided tour. They looked far too pally for my liking.
What’s he doing here? And where’s Turlough?

FX: THEY MOVE THROUGH CROWD.
But if Pallister sees you —

FX: THEY MOVE THROUGH CROWD.

(OVER PREVIOUS LINE) Sorry, not pushing in, just want to speak to a friend —
FX: THEY REACH THE DOCTOR.
(CAGEY) Tegan! Nyssa! What are you doing here?
I was about to ask you the same question.
You can’t stay here. You have to go. If Pallister sees you...

THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 54
There’s no time to explain.
Come on, I know you’re up to something.
Please, Tegan. You’1ll just have to trust me.
Doctor. Where’s Turlough?
(GUILTY) Turlough is.. fine. Listen. Go back to the TARDIS and wait for us there. — Here’s my key. Try not to lose it.
Why are you so chummy with Pallister? He tried to kill me!
Because, Tegan, he’s the only one with the means to get us back to our own universe.
What?
You saw he could send spaceships through the portal. Well, I’m trying to arrange to have the TARDIS put on board the next one out of here.
But I thought the machine needed someone to die to work. A ‘human battery’, you said.
I did. It does.
And you’re happy to go along with that?

I’m sorry, Nyssa. I can’t save everyone.
THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 55

Not just me. You, Nyssa and Turlough. Would you rather I left you here?
Tegan, Pallister’s coming this way. We have to go.

DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 29. INT. GUEST ROOM [SOME TIME LATER]
DOCTOR WHO: WINDOWS.

TURLOUGH: I woke up with a splitting headache in a bare room with a jug of water and a stale loaf on the bedside. Outside the sun was setting in the starless sky. As I was eating, the Doctor entered —

DOCTOR: You, Nyssa and Tegan could. Someone has to remain behind, to act as a power source and close the portal.

DOCTOR: I can’t think of anyone more qualified. I was the one who got you into this mess. It’s my responsibility to get you out.
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 82
TURLOUGH: But you could use anyone — Branarack, one of his pirates —
DOCTOR: I’m not prepared to sacrifice the life of another.
TURLOUGH: But you are prepared to sacrifice your own life.
DOCTOR: I won’t die. All I’1ll lose is my freedom. The least I deserve.
TURLOUGH: And Pallister’s happy to go along with this?
DOCTOR: No. I’ve given him the impression that I’ve improved his machine. In return, he’s agreed to allow us to leave in Branarack’s ship. I had to convince him that I was willing to use another human as a power source, so I accompanied him to the town to select some suitable candidates.
TURLOUGH: And did you?
DOCTOR: They’re in the dungeon. Don’t worry, I’1ll make sure they’re set free, once you’ve gone.
TURLOUGH: What about Nyssa and Tegan? Do they know what you’re planning?
DOCTOR: Not yet. I spoke to them when I was in the town, told them to wait in the TARDIS. Hopefully they’1l have done as I said.
TURLOUGH: Hopefully.
DOCTOR: Indeed. You see, I persuaded Pallister to get his robots to fetch the TARDIS, and place it onboard the Buccaneer.
SENTINEL: Doctor. You are required by Science-Tech Pallister.
DOCTOR: Good news, I hope?
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 83
SENTINEL: Your container has been located and transferred to the spacecraft. Follow, I will take you to it.
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 84
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 31. INT. BUCCANEER [SOME MINUTES LATER]
DOCTOR WHO: CREAKY.
TURLOUGH: (NARRATION) The sentinel led us to the Buccaneer, still resting on the ramp in front of the Portal.
TURLOUGH: (NARRATION)
TURLOUGH: We passed through the airlock into a murky, cramped control room littered with looted trinkets. It smelt heavily of stale sweat and corroded batteries.
PALLISTER: Ah, Doctor. Mind your head. I’m pleased to see your friend has recovered. Tell me, what precisely does this blue box of yours contain?
DOCTOR: Just some items of personal value.
PALLISTER: Not very many, by the look of it.
TURLOUGH: A few souvenirs of our travels in E-Space, that’s all.
PALLISTER: Fascinating. Now, if you will excuse me, I still need to find a subject for the induction chamber. One of Branarack’s crew, perhaps.
DOCTOR: I’1ll meet you later in the power vault. Just got a few things to check first.
TURLOUGH: He’s gone.
DOCTOR: Good. (TO TARDIS) Nyssa, Tegan, if you’re in there, it’s safe to come out. There’s no-one here apart from Turlough and me. Hello?
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 85
TURLOUGH: I don’t think they’re in there.
DOCTOR: No. They must still be in the settlement with that girl,
DOCTOR: Cherryanne.
TURLOUGH: So what now?
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 86
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 32. INT. PALLISTER’S LABORATORY [FEW MINUTES LATER].
PALLISTER: I would not advise leaving the citadel, Doctor. You’ve seen for yourself the conditions out there. If it wasn’t for the Sentinels, we would’ve been mobbed.
DOCTOR: Then let us borrow two Sentinels, for our protection.
PALLISTER: There’s no need. The Sentinels can locate and recover your friends for you.
DOCTOR: You’re in radio contact with all the Sentinels in the settlement?
PALLISTER: Of course. I can give the order right now. I’m quite keen to enjoy Tegan’s company again.
TURLOUGH: I doubt the feeling is mutual.
PALLISTER: What was the other girl’s name again?
DOCTOR: Nyssa. She’s called Nyssa.
PALLISTER: Science-Tech Pallister calling all Sentinels on patrol in the settlement. You are to locate two females, known as Tegan and Nyssa.
SENTINEL: (DISTORT) As commanded.
PALLISTER: Anyone attempting to obstruct your search or withhold them is to be dealt with in the usual fashion.
SENTINEL: (DISTORT) As commanded.
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 87
TURLOUGH: Now what?
PALLISTER: (FX: CHECKING EQUIPMENT) A disturbance in the dungeon. Sentinels, report. Report! Report!
TURLOUGH: They’re not answering.
DOCTOR: Maybe we should go down there and look?
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 88
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 33. INT. PRISON.
DOCTOR WHO: CAGES. SENTINELS CLANKING.
PRISONERS: (CRYING OUT, FEARFUL) Let us out!/ The plague is here! The plague! / Get away from me! Get back! [ETC]
TURLOUGH: (NARRATION)
TURLOUGH: We made our way down to the dungeon, to find the prisoners ina state of terror, heaving at the bars of their cages like wild animals.
PALLISTER: What’s got into them?
DOCTOR: They’re scared. Something’s frightened them out of their wits.
BRANARACK: Pallister! You’ve got to let us out of here! In the name of the fire demons of Valuma!

PALLISTER: Get back! Don’t let them touch you.
BRANARACK: What’re you saying, man? You’ve got to let us out of here! Or we’ll all catch it. And you know what that means!
PALLISTER: What?
BRANARACK: You know what happens to those struck down with entropy plague. What they become. And then these cages won’t be enough to hold us.
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 89
DOCTOR: What’s he talking about?
BRANARACK: Doctor. Do you want to stand by and let us die? Do you?
DOCTOR: No. Tell me what I can do.
BRANARACK: Let us out. Gavlar’s beyond hope now, but the rest of us are plague free.
PALLISTER: No. You’re carriers. All of you.
BRANARACK: Not yet. But if you don’t release us, soon we will be and then not even your Sentinels will be able to save you. Look at them!
PALLISTER: What are you talking about? Sentinel five. Report status.
SENTINEL: Communications malfunction. Corrosion of internal mechanisms. Condition terminal. (REPEAT)
TURLOUGH: So that’s why they weren’t responding. They’re rusting away.
DOCTOR: And so are the bars of the cages.
PALLISTER: (TERRIFIED) They’re infected. They’re all infected.
DOCTOR: You can’t be sure of that. You should establish a quarantine —
PALLISTER: It’s too late for that. (TO SENTINELS) All Sentinels. On my word, you are to open all the holding cages and drive out all the prisoners into the settlement, do you understand?
DOCTOR: But if you do that, you’ll spread the infection!
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 90
PALLISTER: We don’t have any choice. It’s them or us.
BRANARACK: Just let us out of here, you flea-ridden cur! Gavlar’s changing. He’s changing!
SANDMAN: Dust to dust!
TURLOUGH: Doctor, if he says there’s nothing we can do for them, and they’re infectious —
DOCTOR: I can’t let you do this, Pallister —
PALLISTER: All Sentinels, open the cages now! Get them out of here!
PALLISTER: OF SANDMEN. UTTER CHAOS. CONTINUES INTO:
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 91
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 34. INT. PRISON. [CONTINUOUS]
TURLOUGH: (NARRATION) The Sentinels unlocked the cages and the prisoners staggered free, stumbling towards us.
SENTINEL: All tributes are to vacate the citadel. Any attempt to remain will be terminal. (REPEATS IN B/G)
TURLOUGH: (NARRATION) As the Sentinels forced the prisoners out of the citadel, we retreated up the stairs.
PALLISTER: There. Now that should keep them out.
DOCTOR: What about everyone in the settlement? What happens to them?
PALLISTER: They are not my concern. And either you help me open the portal so we can escape this becursed universe, or you are very welcome to join them!
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 92
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 35. INT. PALLISTER’S LABORATORY [LATER]
DOCTOR WHO: B/G.
TURLOUGH: (NARRATION) Pallister ordered his remaining Sentinels to secure the other entrances to the citadel while we returned to his laboratory.
DOCTOR: Pallister, what exactly is the Entropy Plague?
PALLISTER: The second law of dynamics as infection. Incurable and unstoppable, resulting in complete cellular decay and disintegration.
TURLOUGH: You mean they turn to dust?
PALLISTER: Yes. Unfortunately it doesn’t always prove fatal.
DOCTOR: Like Branarack said. The plague transforms the carrier into something else.
PALLISTER: A Sandman. A figure from folklore, but with origins in fact. They feed on energy, on structure, on heat and light. And if you’re so much as touched by a Sandman, you become a Sandman.
TURLOUGH: And you released them into the settlement.
PALLISTER: Which should give us time to get away.
DOCTOR: But if you open the portal you’1ll accelerate the progress of the infection. You’1l make the Sandmen even more powerful.
PALLISTER: As I seem to keep telling you, there is no alternative.
DOCTOR: No. There is. We close the portal. Seal it off. End the energy drain. If that’s what’s generating the Sandmen, then if we close it, they should be scattered to the four winds.
PALLISTER: And we will all be trapped!
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 93
DOCTOR: Not necessarily. To close the CVE, we need to stabilise it, so one last ship will be able to pass through.
TURLOUGH: The Buccaneer.
DOCTOR: But that will be it. The next time the Portal is opened must be the last. We go, the portal closes behind us, forever.
PALLISTER: So long as we get away it hardly matters.
DOCTOR: Of course it matters. There are thousands of people left in this universe. If we can’t evacuate them, we can at least give them a chance of survival.
SENTINEL: (DISTORT) Science-Tech Pallister.
PALLISTER: What is it?
SENTINEL: (DISTORT) Humans are congregating at the main entrance. They claim there are Sandmen in the settlement.
PALLISTER: Unless they offer tributes, and are free of infection, no-one is to enter the citadel, do you understand? No-one!
SENTINEL: (DISTORT) They are climbing the perimeter fence, attempting to enter the grounds.
PALLISTER: Order them to vacate the area. If they refuse, persuade them.
SENTINEL: (DISTORT) As commanded.
TURLOUGH: But you did this, you are responsible. If you leave those people out there, at the mercy of the Sandmen —
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 94
PALLISTER: The Sandmen have no mercy.
TURLOUGH: Exactly.
DOCTOR: Turlough’s right. You have to let them in!
PALLISTER: It’s too late for that. They must take their own chances.
TURLOUGH: Doctor. Tegan and Nyssa are out there.
DOCTOR: I hadn’t forgotten.
PALLISTER: If they are still alive, my Sentinels will find them. But in the meantime, we have preparations to make.
DOCTOR: You agree? You’1ll use your machine to close the CVE?
PALLISTER: I agree. One of my Sentinels can operate it, once we are safely on board the Buccaneer.
DOCTOR: There’1ll be no need for that.
PALLISTER: No?
DOCTOR: I’m offering myself as tribute. If it means I get my friends home, it’s a sacrifice I’m willing to make.
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 95
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 36. INT. GENERATOR ROOM [LATER]
TURLOUGH: (NARRATION)
TURLOUGH: The Doctor and Pallister went to the vault to work on the generator while I remained in the laboratory, staying in contact with the Sentinels.
SENTINEL: (DISTORT) The females known as Tegan and Nyssa have been located.
TURLOUGH: What? Are they alive?
SENTINEL: (DISTORT) They are both animate. They were with another female, known as
SENTINEL: Cherryanne.
TURLOUGH: Bring them all into the citadel through the west-gate.
SENTINEL: (DISTORT) As commanded.
TURLOUGH: Doctor? Hello?
DOCTOR: (VIA INTERCOM) Turlough, what is it?
TURLOUGH: Tegan and Nyssa, they’re alive, and being brought here now.
DOCTOR: (VIA INTERCOM) Marvellous. Pallister and I just have a few finishing touches to make, and I’1ll meet you all in the power vault.
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 96
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 37. INT. POWER VAULT [LATER].
TURLOUGH: (NARRATION)
TURLOUGH: I waited for the Doctor in the power vault. A few minutes later he arrived, and then a Sentinel led in three figures dressed in hooded cloaks.
NYSSA: Doctor!
DOCTOR: Nyssa, Tegan, and, eYF...
CHERRYANNE: Cherryanne.
DOCTOR: Yes, I remember. — You’re all unharmed, I trust?
TEGAN: Just about. We were in Cherryanne’s hut when her brother became one of those Sandman things. Then this robot turned up, grabbed us, and frogmarched us here.
NYSSA: You should see it out there, Doctor. It’s like a war zone.
TEGAN: Sandmen and robots killing people, people begging to get into this place.
CHERRYANNE: It’s like the world is coming to an end.
DOCTOR: Not just a world, the entire universe. It can’t have more than a few hours left.
TEGAN: We can’t just pretend it’s not happening. Doctor, we have to do something!
DOCTOR: Yes. That’s why I’ve arranged with Pallister for you three to be on board the last ship to pass through the CVE.
TEGAN: I didn’t mean make a deal with that sadist! I meant —
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 97
DOCTOR: Necessity makes strange bedfellows. The TARDIS is already in the ship. Once you’re back in N-Space, it will re-activate, and you’ll be able to contact the Time Lords. They’1l be able to get you all home.
TEGAN: You’re talking like you won’t be with us.
DOCTOR: I won’t. Someone needs to act as a power source.
NYSSA: And that person gets left behind...
DOCTOR: Yes. — So you see, that person should be me.
TEGAN: Doctor, you’re not listening.
NYSSA: We can’t abandon anyone! Not you, and not the people of E- Space!
DOCTOR: Please, listen to me. Once the CVE is closed, the energy drain will cease and the Sandmen will turn to dust. This world will still have centuries left.
TEGAN: Oh. Right. — Still, you’d never be able to return to our universe.
DOCTOR: Rather me than any of you. And Cherryanne — you can go on the ship too, if you like.
CHERRYANNE: Thank you. I would like that very much.
NYSSA: No.
TURLOUGH: Why are we still arguing?!
NYSSA: There are people suffering out there, Doctor. Not just from the plague. From malnutrition, from exhaustion. We can’t just leave them.
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 98
DOCTOR: If you’re ever going to return to N-Space, we don’t have any choice.
NYSSA: No, Doctor. There is another way. I can be the power source. I should be the one who stays.
DOCTOR: No, Nyssa. You have a son and daughter.
NYSSA: Out of all of us, who can do the most good here? Me, Doctor. It’s me. I'll be able to save lives, to tend to the sick. It’s what I’ve always done. It’s what I was brought up to do.
DOCTOR: I’m not going to argue with you, Nyssa.
NYSSA: I can’t let you sacrifice yourself, Doctor. You have so much more life left to live. But me? I’ve lived a long time. Look at me.
TURLOUGH: (NARRATION)
TURLOUGH: As Nyssa spoke, she drew back the hood of her cloak, to reveal her skin was lined and her hair was streaked with grey. She looked even older than she did when we met her on Helheim.
DOCTOR: Oh no...
NYSSA: Yes. My rejuvenation has been reversed. I’m starting to look and feel my real age.
DOCTOR: The effect of exposure to accelerated entropy.
NYSSA: Exactly, Doctor. The same thing that destroyed my home planet, and now it’s killing me.
TEGAN: But you can be cured. Once we’re back in N-Space, you’1ll be back to normal? Won’t she, Doctor? (BEAT) Won’t she?
DOCTOR: There is no cure. It’s an immutable law. Entropy increases.
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 99
NYSSA: Which is why I must stay, and you must go. Go and find my son and daughter. Tell them that I chose to remain here. Tell them that I love them, that I will always love them —
DOCTOR: Nyssa, no.
NYSSA: You have to let me do this, Doctor. You have to let me be the one who stays behind.
NYSSA: END OF PART THREE
DOCTOR WHO: THE ENTROPY PLAGUE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 100
